text.__SUMMARY__: Pandanus elatus is a dioecious tropical plant in the screwpine genus.  It is endemic to Christmas Island, an Australian territory in the north-eastern Indian Ocean.  Its specific epithet comes from the Latin elatus (tall), in reference to its growth habit.
text.Description: Pandanus elatus is an erect tree, with basal prop roots, that grows to 20 m in height.  Its leaves grow to 3 m long and 100 mm wide, dark green and with marginal prickles.  The plants do not form the densely tangled thickets that characterise P. christmatensis.
text.Distribution and habitat: Found only on Christmas Island, the tree is found on deeper soils in the rainforest, sometimes in small groves.
text.Taxonomy: The tree is closely related to P. leram Jones, of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands and the southern coasts of Sumatra and western Java.
text.References-Sources:
Ridley, H.N. (1906). Journal of the Straits Branch of the Royal Asiatic Society. 45: 239. 
"Pandanus elatus Ridl". Flora of Australia Online. Australian Biological Resources Study. 1993. Retrieved 2010-11-23.
